timeline.summary: An FBI Forensic Accountant at the New York Field Office is investigating property ownership linked to Ghislaine Maxwell. Communications detail a potential property value of $4,950,000 sold by an LLC on July 6, 2000, to an unknown buyer. The initial investigation indicates the property was previously owned by an LLC and potentially partially or fully owned by Ghislaine Maxwell. The investigator requests further information including purchase and sale dates, prices, and previous owners from various real estate databases (ACRIS).

A case involving CP (likely child pornography) originated from multiple uploads to Yahoo photo albums and the seizure of four computers from a defendant’s residence. Forensics revealed a virtual reality game, “Hizashi no nakano real,” featuring a 10-year-old animated Asian girl being sexually molested. The defendant was the only user of the game and had progressed to Level 4, involving sustained graphic acts. The case’s admissibility is being questioned.

Goodman, a highly experienced psychologist specializing in the intersection of developmental psychology, memory, and the legal system, particularly concerning child sexual abuse. **Key Information:** *   **Background:** Dr. Goodman holds a Ph.D. from UCLA and has a distinguished career marked by extensive research, teaching, and consulting roles. *   **Academic Affiliations:** She has held prominent positions at the University of California, Davis, including Distinguished Professor of Psychology and Director of the Center for Public Policy Research. She has also held positions at the University of Oslo and the University of Denver. *   **Research Focus:** Her research primarily revolves around children’s memory, eyewitness testimony, false memory, trauma, attachment, and how these factors relate to legal cases involving child abuse. She has conducted numerous studies with various methods (e.g., laboratory experiments, longitudinal studies, clinical interviews). *   **Professional Memberships:** Dr. Goodman is a fellow of several prominent psychological organizations, including the American Psychological Association and the Society for Psychological Study of Social Issues. *   **Awards and Recognition:** She has received numerous prestigious awards and honors, including the UC Davis Academic Senate Distinguished Faculty Research Award and the American Psychological Association's Distinguished Contributions to Research in Public Interest Award. *   **Consulting and Expertise:** Dr. Goodman has served as a consultant to special assault forensic evaluation centers and has been involved in advising governmental and legal agencies on child abuse cases. She has testified in court and given numerous invited lectures. *   **Publications and Contributions:** She has authored and co-authored numerous scholarly articles, book chapters, and reports on child witness testimony and related topics. *   **Ongoing Research:** Dr. Goodman continues to conduct research in this field, exploring topics such as memory accuracy, false memory, and the influence of attachment on memory processes. In essence, this document showcases Gail Goodman’s substantial and impactful contributions to the field of psychology, particularly in understanding the complexities of memory and its relevance in legal contexts related to child abuse.

This document is a Suicide Watch/Psych Observation update regarding subject EFTA00035289. It includes a note regarding Epstein #76318-054 and a closing statement from a forensic observer (EFTA00035290).
Inmate EFTA00035672 is under Suicide Watch and Psych Observation. Specifically, inmate Stein #76318-054 is under Psych Observation. The update was sent on July 9, 2019, from [REDACTED].

On July 9, 2019, a report was submitted regarding a suicide watch and psychological observation. The subjects under observation were Epstein (#76318-054) and Gebremariam (#79792-007), with Gebremariam designated as forensic. The report was classified as confidential and associated with case number SDNY_00012728.

The document is a communication regarding a suicide watch and psychiatric observation. Individuals listed for observation are Epstein (#76318-054) and Gebremariam (#79792-007), with Gebremariam noted as being under forensic observation. The communication is classified as confidential and originates from the SDNY_00009862 source.
Inmate Epstein (#76318-054) is being placed on Psych Observation. The Suicide Watch status is None. This update was sent on July 9, 2019, at 12:33:16 PM.

*   On July 9th, the watch was noted as “None.” *   On July 10th, Epstein was moved from Psychological Observation to the SHU. *   On July 23rd and 24th, Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation. *   A Forensic Psychologist, LT, U.S. Public Health Service, was involved in the observation of Gebremariam (ID: 79792-007). *   All updates contained a disclaimer regarding sensitive information.

This document is a suicide watch/psych observation update, dated July 10, 2019, sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED]. It includes observations for two individuals: E stein #76318-054 and #79792-007 (Forensic). The document is classified as CONFIDENTIAL and includes the case ID SDNY_00009866.
A suicide watch observation was initiated for patient E stein #76318-054. The observation was flagged as (Forensic). The update was sent on July 10, 2019, at 11:29:51 AM from [REDACTED].
A suicide watch observation was initiated for patient E stein #76318-054. The observation was conducted as part of a forensic evaluation (SDNY_000 12734) and documented on July 10, 2019.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] on July 10, 2019, regarding a "Suicide Watch" under the case number EFTA00035291. The email included a forensic observation of patient E stein #76318-054 and a closing statement from EFTA00035292.

On July 10, 2019, Inmate Epstein #76318-054 was removed from Psychological Observation and placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). There were no active Suicide Watches reported. The update was provided by Forensic Psychologist Samantha (Forensic) of the U.S. Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Prisons, Metropolitan Correctional Center.

Inmate Epstein #76318-054 was removed from Psychological Observation and placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on July 10, 2019. There were no active Suicide Watches at that time. The update was provided by a Forensic Psychologist with the U.S. Public Health Service and the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

This document is a search and seizure warrant issued by a U.S. Magistrate Judge for a case related to violations of Title 18 U.S. Code, Sections 371 and 1591 (sex trafficking of minors). The warrant authorizes the search of a residence at 9 East 71st Street, New York, NY, and the seizure of computer devices and storage media that may contain electronically stored information related to sex trafficking. Specifically, the warrant seeks evidence of child sexual exploitation, including photographs, communications, and data related to victims or potential victims. The warrant allows for forensic examination of the seized devices and their contents, utilizing techniques like keyword searches and file reviews. A 30-day delay of notification is authorized to prevent potential adverse results. The document includes details of the warrant execution, return, and inventory procedures.

This document is a supplemental brief filed by Marc Fernich’s law office in response to the government’s arguments for Jeffrey Epstein’s continued detention in the SDNY case (19 CR 490). The core argument is against the government’s assertion that Epstein’s wealth creates an irrebuttable presumption against his release, arguing instead that conditions can be established to ensure his appearance and safety. Specifically, the brief contends: *   The government’s argument misinterprets the 18 USC § 1591 remand presumption and relies on a flawed assumption that Epstein’s wealth automatically disqualifies him from bail. *   Suitable conditions, such as a forensic accounting of his finances and co-signers like his brother Mark with a substantial net worth, can adequately mitigate any perceived risk. *   The government’s claims regarding witness payments were actually for long-time friends and employees, not victims, and the Austrian passport is expired and irrelevant. *   Recidivism rates are subject to debate, and there's no evidence to suggest Epstein would flee or be a flight risk given his financial resources and established ties. The document concludes by requesting the Court to consider these arguments and propose appropriate conditions for release if it decides to grant bail.

An FBI investigation, involving a forensic accountant, is underway regarding financial documents related to the Epstein case. A contractor ([REDACTED]) was instructed to burn specified folders to a disc and deliver it to a Special Agent at a conference or via security pickup by 11:30 AM. The folders included documents related to American Express and Deutsche Bank subpoenas. The request originated from an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

This document is a search warrant issued on July 21, 2019, by U.S. Magistrate Judge Barbara Moses for a search of property located at 9 East 71st Street, New York, NY. The warrant targets compact discs seized on July 7, 2019, and seeks to uncover evidence related to violations of Title 18, U.S. Code, Sections 371 and 1591 (sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy).  Specifically, investigators are authorized to seize documents, photographs, and recordings depicting minors engaged in sexually explicit conduct, as well as items related to the ownership or use of electronic devices involved in these activities. The warrant includes provisions for a forensic image of the seized devices and a thorough review of the electronic storage information (ESI) contained within, utilizing various search techniques.  A detailed inventory and return form is attached to the warrant, outlining the specific items being sought.

Attorney are coordinating a meeting to review financial documents related to Jeffrey Epstein. The initial scheduling involved multiple attempts to find a suitable time for a call, primarily between July 23, 2019, and July 18, 2019. A forensic accountant is assisting in the investigation.  A request was made to burn and deliver specific folders relating to American Express and Deutsche Bank subpoenas to the FBI for review, with the expectation of presenting the discs at a conference.

The document records email exchanges regarding a financial investigation related to Jeffrey Epstein, overseen by the FBI and the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York. Discussions involve scheduling a call to review financial documents, coordinating with a forensic accountant, and arranging for the delivery of digital media containing subpoena returns from American Express and Deutsche Bank. The initial request was for a call at 1:30 PM on July 23, 2019, with subsequent scheduling adjustments and coordination for a meeting to discuss a game plan.

Attorney’s office, are coordinating regarding the “Epstein” financial documents (EFTA00030628 and EFTA00030629). *   Discussions involve scheduling a call for July 23rd at 1:30 PM, arranging a meeting to discuss a game plan for the investigation, and the delivery of discs containing relevant financial data. *   A contractor, Hamilton, is tasked with creating and delivering the discs. *   The FBI is involved in overseeing the process and coordinating with the forensic accountant.

The document is a record of communication regarding the investigation of financial documents related to Jeffrey Epstein, involving the FBI’s New York field office (N. (NY) (FBI)) and a contractor, Andy Hamilton. Key points include: *   Scheduling a call between FBI agents and Alison [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] to discuss the documents. *   A forensic accountant, Lubin, is being brought in to assist. *   Hamilton was instructed to burn specific folders to a disc and deliver it to Special Agent Amanda Young by 11:30 AM for a scheduled conference or via a security pickup. *   The subject of the communications is the “USvEpstein-2018R01618 InvestigationVI 2018 SDNY” investigation.

A forensic psychologist from the U.S. Public Health Service, working for the Bureau of Prisons, sent an email to a redacted recipient regarding “Epstein #76318-054.” The email attached a PDF document titled “2019 07 24 10 40 50.pdf,” and included a warning that the message contained sensitive information requiring specific handling according to policy.

An inmate, identified as Epstein #76318-054, is currently on Psychological Observation and requests to receive his legal paperwork, which is permitted. The communication originates from a Forensic Psychologist within the U.S. Department of Justice’s Federal Bureau of Prisons, Metropolitan Correctional Center, and is directed to prison staff.

On July 24, 2019, a suicide watch was initiated for Epstein #76318-054, a Forensic Psychologist with the U.S. Public Health Service and Federal Bureau of Prisons, who was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The communication was classified as CONFIDENTIAL and contained sensitive information regarding the case (EFTA00034658).

On July 24, 2019, a Suicide Watch was initiated for inmate Epstein (#76318-054) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The update was provided by a Forensic Psychologist, LT, U.S. Public Health Service, from the U.S. Department of Justice’s Federal Bureau of Prisons. The fax included a confidentiality warning regarding sensitive information.

On July 24, 2019, a Lieutenant within the U.S. Public Health Service and Federal Bureau of Prisons (Metropolitan Correctional Center) requested a change in observation status for inmate Epstein #76318-054. The request involved removing him from Suicide Watch and placing him on Psychological Observation, as documented in a memorandum from the MCC New York. A forensic report named “TEXT.htm” and a PDF file were attached to the communication.

A forensic psychologist working for the U.S. Public Health Service, U.S. Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Prisons, and Metropolitan Correctional Center sent an email attachment, “2019 07 24 10 40 50.odf,” referencing case file #76318-054 concerning Jeffrey Epstein. The email was marked CONFIDENTIAL and SDNY_000 11865 and EFTA00034654.

On July 29, 2019, at 11:29 AM, a Forensic Psychologist with the U.S. Public Health Service and the Federal Bureau of Prisons observed inmate Epstein (#76318-054) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The suicide watch status was clear (None), and the observation was pending beds for the inmate in SHU (Special Housing Unit). The message was classified as CONFIDENTIAL and contained warnings about sensitive information.

Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the case against him (United States v. Jeffrey Epstein, No. 19-cr-00490). The request seeks extensive discovery materials, including: *   **Statements & Recordings:** All government interviews, transcripts, and recordings involving Epstein. *   **Government Agencies:** Information from the FBI, DOJ, SEC, DHS, NYPD, Palm Beach County Sheriff’s Office, NM Attorney General's Office, and other local/foreign law enforcement entities involved in the investigation. *   **Private Entities:** Information from private investigators assisting the government. *   **Brady Material:**  Exculpatory evidence, materials that would mitigate guilt, or impeachment evidence. *   **Jencks Material:**  Witness statements and materials intended to be presented at trial. *   **Scientific Evidence:**  Records related to forensic examinations, surveillance, and other scientific procedures. *   **Grand Jury Information:** Details about grand jury proceedings, including witness lists, transcripts, and instructions. *   **Seized Information:** Review of any seized materials, particularly addressing responsive and privileged materials. The request emphasizes compliance with Brady v. Maryland and Rule 16(c) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, requesting immediate disclosure and ongoing supplementation. It specifically requests the government to identify and provide the source material for any information disclosed, not just summaries.  It further asserts the need to protect attorney-client privilege and work-product.

A forensic psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York requested a 15-day extension to complete evaluations due to understaffing, a high caseload, and a pending medical procedure. Supporting correspondence details requests, confirmations, and acknowledgments related to the extension request and the psychologist's role within the U.S. Public Health Service, Department of Justice, and Federal Bureau of Prisons. The document includes email chains discussing the situation and attached documents, including a letter to the Judge. Redactions have been applied to several sections of the document.

On August 9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at WAB-USMS-SDNY, leading to a medical emergency and subsequent death. Initial events included an inmate departure for court, visits with attorneys, and a social call. CPR and medical interventions were performed, and he was transported to Beekman Hospital. A timeline of responses followed, involving law enforcement (FBI, USMS), legal personnel (AUSA, Judge Berman), medical staff (Medical Examiner, Psychologist), and institutional staff (warden, correctional officers, IT staff). Investigations spanned multiple days, including interviews, fingerprint collection, forensic examinations, and the removal of electronic devices. The investigation involved numerous agencies and personnel, culminating in the release of the body for autopsy and the resumption of normal operations on August 11, 2019.

On August 9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at WAB, prompting CPR and subsequent medical intervention. He was transported to Beekman Hospital where he died at 7:30 am. Following his death, authorities conducted interviews with inmates, collected forensic evidence, notified legal representatives and the media, and arranged for the body to be released for autopsy. The timeline details staff responses, medical procedures, law enforcement involvement, and communication with key personnel including the FBI, prosecutor’s office, and family.

CPR and various medical interventions were attempted. Emergency services were called, and he was transported to Beekman Hospital. A timeline of events followed, including notifications to various authorities (FBI, USMS, AUSA, Judge Berman), institutional staff, and psychological professionals.  A press release was issued, and the body was released to the Medical Examiner for autopsy. Investigations involved interviews with inmates, forensic examination (fingerprints, photos), computer removal and replacement, and involvement from the FBI, OIG, and correctional services personnel over several days. Normal operations resumed on August 11, 2019, with continued investigations extending into August 13, 2019 involving additional correctional services personnel.

On August 9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was unresponsive in his cell at WAB, prompting medical intervention and subsequent transport to Beekman Hospital. CPR, epinephrine, and IV access were administered without success. He was pronounced dead at 7:36 am. Following his death, authorities, including the FBI, USMS, SIS, and various hospital and correctional staff, responded to the scene and initiated an investigation. Interviews were conducted with inmates, forensic examinations were performed, and the body was released to the Medical Examiner for autopsy. The timeline details the communication and actions of numerous agencies and individuals involved in the response, including notification of legal representatives, media, and oversight agencies.

Medical personnel initiated CPR and other life-saving measures, leading to intubation and administration of epinephrine. He was transported to Beekman Hospital where he was pronounced dead at 7:36 am. The incident triggered a rapid response involving multiple agencies including the US Marshals Service, FBI, District Attorney’s office, medical staff, psychological staff, and various institutional personnel. Investigations included interviews with inmates, collection of forensic evidence (fingerprints, photographs, clothing), and the removal of electronic devices from his cell. The autopsy was conducted on August 12, 2019, and forensic teams (OIG/FBI) collected computer data. The timeline details the coordination of these efforts, communications with relevant parties, and the actions taken by various individuals and organizations involved in the response.

Jeffrey Epstein’s death occurred on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The timeline begins with his court appearance at 8:30 am, followed by a social call at 7:00 pm. At 6:33 am on August 10th, a body alarm was triggered, and Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell. Medical personnel initiated CPR and provided interventions before transporting him to Beekman Hospital. Despite efforts, he was pronounced dead at 7:36 am. A series of agencies, including US Marshals, FBI, Bureau of Prisons, and the Office of the Inspector General (OIG), responded to the scene and conducted investigations, including interviews, forensic examinations (fingerprints, photographs, autopsy), and the removal of electronic devices. The investigation continued into the following day, with OIG and FBI agents collecting evidence and computers before departing the institution.

A Forensic Psychologist is requesting emails from a recipient (identified as “can_mi”) regarding communications involving Jeffrey Epstein. The request includes specific questions about whether the recipient has emails where Epstein needed a cellmate or other emails concerning Epstein. The communication is classified as CONFIDENTIAL and involves the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

A forensic psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City, requesting emails related to Jeffrey Epstein, specifically inquiring about instances where Epstein needed a cellmate or any other emails concerning Epstein. The email was sent on August 12, 2019.

On August 14, 2019, a Forensic Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center reported that the Suicide Watch light in Cell #1 was out due to an inmate's occupancy. The Psychologist requested immediate replacement of the light and instructed the Lieutenant to move the inmate to another cell while the repair was conducted. The email thread confirms the situation and the urgency of the repair.

An FBI Forensic Accountant from the New York Field Office is reviewing Maxwell’s credit card accounts, specifically a CapitalOne/SAKS card (account number redacted).  The attached Experian report from August 2019 shows the card had a zero balance as of August 15, 2019, with the last payment made in May 2019. A summary of Maxwell’s credit cards is being prepared and will be sent out either today or tomorrow.

A Forensic Accountant at the FBI New York Field Office is requesting subpoenas from Wells Fargo, CITI, MoneyGram, Western Union, and Experian. Attached riders are provided for the subpoenas, which the Forensic Accountant will serve. Recipients are instructed to use specific contact information for the FBI and to forward results electronically to 26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY 10278.

On August 15, 2019, an FBI update regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case was shared between FBI offices in New York and Virginia. A case coordination meeting was scheduled for August 16, 2019, at 10:00 AM at SDNY to discuss strategy following Epstein’s death. Evidence from Little St. James, USVI, was being processed for forensic analysis by the Evidence Control Unit and CART.

A subpoena request was sent from the Assistant United States Attorney, Southern District of New York, to various financial institutions – Wells Fargo, Citibank, MoneyGram, Western Union, and Experian – on August 16, 2019. The subpoenas were to be prepared and returned by the FBI Forensic Accountant, with specific text to be included. The FBI Special Agent was designated as the point of contact for the FBI’s investigation, and the results were to be submitted electronically to the FBI New York Field Office.

An email chain discusses the preparation and return of subpoenas related to Wells Fargo, CITI, MoneyGram, Western Union, and Experian. The subpoenas should include the text: “If you have any questions please contact Forensic Accountant.” The subpoenas were requested by an Assistant United States Attorney and the FBI, specifically referencing Special Agent EFTA00032383.

A case coordination meeting is scheduled for August 16, 2019, at 10:00 am at SDNY to discuss strategy following Jeffrey Epstein’s death. Evidence seized from Little St. James, USVI, is being processed for forensic analysis by CART. The FBI New York, Squad C-20, is handling Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking related to EFTA00037359.

FBI New York is coordinating daily conference calls at 3:30 PM regarding the Epstein case. The calls utilize the VCAC Bridge Line. Information regarding “dial-in details” is being forwarded between FBI agents and [REDACTED]. The purpose of the calls is to discuss aspects of the case and forensics, with a focus on a jail incident.  SSA, FBI New York, CID (FBI), and ASAC personnel are involved in these daily calls.

On August 27, 2019, an FBI investigation (Serial 90A-NY-3151227) involving an Apple iPhone XS (IMEI: 1B44, iOS 12.4) was conducted. An ITS/Forensic Examiner performed a file system extraction using GrayKey v1.11.10 in response to MDUS request 110754. No unlock PIN was associated with the device. A SHA256 hash was generated, and extraction files were copied to an external hard drive. The extracted item and resulting evidence were returned to the New York CART, and the examination portion is considered complete. The document is FBI property and restricted for distribution outside the agency.

A forensic psychologist, Ph.D., is out of the office from August 12 to September 3, 2019, with email access limited.  The psychologist advises contacting the Lieutenant’s Office (Ext. 6450) for emergencies or contacting designated personnel for psychology-related issues.  An OIG (Office of the Inspector General) is requesting an interview regarding Jeffrey Epstein, registration number 76318-054.  The OIG wants to interview staff members including a nurse, and the medical staff are available for voluntary interviews.

Dawn M. Hughes, Ph.D., ABPP, is a clinical and forensic psychologist specializing in traumatic stress, interpersonal violence, and anxiety disorders. She holds degrees from Nova Southeastern University and has extensive professional experience, including postdoctoral fellowships, clinical practice, and academic positions at Well Cornell Medical College. Her licensure includes New York, Connecticut, and North Carolina. She is a member of numerous professional organizations, including the American Psychological Association and the International Society for Traumatic Stress Studies. Hughes has a significant record of professional activities and presentations, frequently lecturing on forensic psychology, trauma assessment, and courtroom strategies related to interpersonal violence.  Her research focuses on memory of childhood sexual abuse and its psychological effects.

A timeline report analyzing digital forensic reports from two computers retrieved from the SHU was created by the U.S. Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General, New York Field Office. The report was generated in response to a negative assessment of computer activity and a request for copies of documents accessed by Thomas during his shift.

An FBI agent (Senior Forensic Examiner) requested a call to discuss a list of materials received by CART regarding search warrant materials from the New York house search related to Jeffrey Epstein. An Assistant U.S. Attorney contacted the Senior Forensic Examiner to inquire about the number of electronic devices (approximately 38 computers/devices and 55 CDs) sent to CART for processing and the number that were subsequently returned. The Senior Forensic Examiner had already contacted someone who handled Epstein evidence and was able to provide information about the materials processed.

An FBI agent (NY) sent an email to Mina regarding search warrant materials from the New York house search related to Jeffrey Epstein. The agent states that load files containing over 800,000 emails are incomplete due to a limitation of 25,000 entries per file. Priority was given to materials from “the Island” with an expiration date. All content is available for taint review in FTK. The agent previously contacted a senior forensic examiner regarding Epstein evidence processed by CART, and an Assistant U.S. Attorney requested information on the number of electronic devices sent to CART and those subsequently processed. Approximately 38 computers/storage devices and 55 CDs were seized and sent to CART for processing.

A discussion occurred regarding a Fox News report concerning the death of Jeffrey Epstein, specifically the opinion of forensic pathologist Dr. Baden, who believes the case is more consistent with strangulation rather than a suicide. A correspondent advised caution and downplaying of “hysteria,” citing the controversial nature of the source. The discussion originated from emails exchanged on October 30, 2019, referencing Dr. Baden's analysis and a statement from Epstein’s brother who expressed frustration regarding unanswered questions.

An Assistant United States Attorney sent a subpoena (attached as 2019-10-07_subpoena_tolapdf) to [REDACTED] requesting a subpoena for CapitalOne regarding a specific matter. The subpoena should include provided text and utilize an account number found by [REDACTED]. The Forensic Accountant at the FBI New York Field Office (26 Federal Plaza, NYC, NY 10278) was to forward results electronically to the Special Agent Federal Bureau of Investigation.

On November 20, 2019, the FBI’s New York Division requested a forensic examination of an Apple iPhone Xs (model A1920, S/N: F17XD9PKKPFW, IMEI: 357208091738649) obtained via Consent to Search. The examination, conducted by the Computer Analysis Response Team (CART), involved a physical inventory, data extractions from the device and SIM card using commercial software, and a request for a full file system extraction. Data was extracted on 9/17/2019, and a report was generated.  Two archived copies of the data were created and released to the New York Division Evidence Control Unit: 1644_NYCO25647 and 1646_NYFO1278. The Sprint SIM Card (ICCID: 89312530002006358152) was also extracted and archived.

An email was sent from an FBI Forensic Accountant at the New York Field Office (EFTA00037689) to an unidentified recipient regarding “Clear & Accurint Rpts.” An attachment named “Clear_Rpt.pdf” was included.

An individual advised caution regarding inquiries about a Fox News report concerning forensic pathologist Jeffrey Baden's assessment of Jeffrey Epstein’s death, suggesting the source is controversial and potentially causing hysteria. Baden stated his findings are more consistent with strangulation rather than a suicide hanging, based on his 50 years of experience.

A Senior Forensic Examiner is generating load files related to electronic evidence from a New York residence search connected to Jeffrey Epstein. The files, expected to be ready by Thursday COB, involve approximately 5-6 iMacs and 5 laptop computers processed by CART. An Assistant U.S. Attorney is following up on the status of these files and requesting information regarding materials from the island that require processing, along with an estimated completion time.

Bruce Barket, representing Barket Epstein Kearon Aldea & LoTurco, LLP, is corresponding with Aida Leisenring and others regarding discovery requests related to the Tartaglione case. Key points include: *   A request for the taint team to contact them regarding a review of a cell phone, specifically concerning hand-held videos from July 23rd. *   An inquiry regarding the inconsistent accounts of surveillance video and a request for further inquiries. *   A request for a hearing regarding the disappearance of surveillance video. *   MCC offers access to a makeshift rope for inspection, with restrictions on photography. *   BOP has forensic reports of Tartaglione’s cellphone and SIM card, which will be reviewed by a walled-off team of AUSAs to identify privileged materials. *   BOP states no other pictures or videos were taken from inside the cell, and a letter with video evidence is forthcoming for review at the office.

An FBI agent (NY) is requesting information about two sets of electronic devices. One set is a batch of search warrant returns from January 13, and the other is a hard drive received last week. The agent needs a list of the devices contained in each set. The communication involves an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York and a Senior Forensic Examiner.

On March 9, 2020, the FBI New York Field Office’s Violent Crimes Task Force received an update from the Digital Forensic Analysis Unit (DFAU) regarding DVR 1. DFAU obtained the password from the MCC Contractor and is currently reviewing the data. DVR 2, covering the MCC SHU, is not running and the MCC Contractor is scheduled to begin working with DFAU in the OTD Lab the following day.

The document details a significant challenge in reviewing a massive collection of electronic data seized in connection with the Epstein investigation. The FBI’s forensic team in New York received over 1.4 million documents from multiple sources, including hard drives and CDs, but the data is severely disorganized and lacks crucial metadata. Specifically, the files are not linked to their originating devices, there’s no indication of whether they represent full or partial data sets, and control numbers are inconsistent. The team repeatedly requested a standardized system—a spreadsheet identifying devices, review status, and data transfers—to facilitate the review process, but faced delays due to network issues and a lack of coordination. Multiple emails exchanged between FBI personnel and U.S. Attorneys highlight the difficulties in tracking the data, the need for a clear accounting of received materials, and the urgency of establishing a systematic review approach before significant time is lost.

A key issue is the slow and inconsistent delivery of data from the FBI. Initially, the FBI planned to provide fully processed data ready for upload to Relativity, but this shifted to providing raw files from the seized devices, requiring the recipient to perform the necessary conversions and processing themselves – a task that proved significantly delayed and complex. The recipient (identified as "USANYS") expressed frustration with the lack of clear communication, the volume of data, and the technical challenges involved in preparing it for review (taint analysis) within Relativity. There were issues with the format of the data, including a lack of linking between email attachments and documents, and the inability of the Relativity platform to handle forensic data elements. The process involved multiple rounds of communication, spreadsheet updates, and requests for additional resources to address the delays. The recipient repeatedly highlighted the need for a clear system of device identification and data tracking to manage the massive amount of information and ensure accurate review. The delays were partly attributed to the FBI's temporary network issues and their decision to send hard drives instead of uploading data directly.

This document details the ongoing efforts to process and review digital evidence seized in connection with the Epstein investigation. Initial challenges involve a disorganized data transfer process, with multiple versions of files and unclear attribution to specific devices. Key issues include: *   **Data Delivery Problems:** Multiple delivery attempts were unsuccessful, with files corrupted or incorrectly formatted, requiring re-transmission. *   **Relativity’s Limitations:** The use of Relativity for taint review was deemed problematic due to the tool's inability to handle forensic data, requiring manual re-processing. *   **Lack of Standardization:** A lack of a standardized system for identifying and tracking data transfers hindered progress, leading to confusion regarding the completeness and origin of files. The need for a spreadsheet detailing devices, data dumps, and review status was repeatedly emphasized. *   **Volume of Data:** The sheer volume of data (over a million documents and numerous devices) created significant logistical and processing challenges. *   **Coordination Issues:** Communication and coordination between the FBI, the U.S. Attorney’s Office, and contractors were essential, but initially hampered by differing approaches and a lack of clear communication about data processing steps. *   **Timeline Concerns:** There were concerns about the timeline for complete data review, initially estimated at a month, but potentially extended due to the complexities involved.

A forensic accountant at the FBI New York Field Office received a subpoena tracker from an unidentified sender on June 2, 2020. The tracker, attached to an email, only contained subpoenas served by the FBI and excluded the Epstein Deutsche Bank production. The sender proposed setting up a Dal virtual drive for shared access.

A forensic accountant from the FBI New York Field Office sent a subpoena tracker (Epstein_Subpoena_Tracker V6.1.20.xlsx) to an individual, including information on subpoenas served by the FBI. The tracker excludes the Epstein-Deutsche Bank production. The accountant offered to provide missing productions and discussed the possibility of a shared Dal virtual drive.

An FBI Forensic Accountant at the New York Field Office is requesting access to USAfx. The request stems from an inability to locate subpoena returns previously provided by a U.S. Attorney’s Office paralegal specialist in SDNY, who previously sent returns on discs. The paralegal specialist is asking for the returns to be uploaded to USAfx.

On June 16, 2020, Ori (from the FBI New York Field Office, EFTA00037701) requested Mark to serve a subpoena related to a CITI account belonging to Maxwell. The subpoena was sent by a Forensic Accountant at the FBI New York Field Office.

An FBI Forensic Accountant from the New York Field Office sent an email to [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] regarding a CITI account belonging to Maxwell ([REDACTED]). The email included the reference number EFTA00037700. A PDF attachment named UBSTERRAMAR00000582.pdf was included.

Initially, there were significant challenges in receiving usable data, stemming from network issues, formatting discrepancies, and a lack of clear identification of the seized devices and their contents.  The FBI contractor, [REDACTED], was responsible for transferring the data, while the US Attorney’s Office (specifically, the NY CART Coordinator) was handling the data review and taint analysis. Key issues included: *   **Data Format Problems:** The received data frequently lacked proper formatting and identification, making it difficult to process and link to specific devices. *   **Delayed Transfers:** Network outages and technical difficulties caused delays in receiving the data. *   **Communication Gaps:** There were misunderstandings and a need for clearer communication regarding the data’s origin, completeness, and transfer process. *   **Need for Tracking:** A central spreadsheet was repeatedly requested to track devices, data transfers, and review status. *   **Processing Needs:** Relativity was being used as the system for review, but it was limited in its ability to handle the data’s complexities. The correspondence highlights a struggle to coordinate efforts, establish clear protocols, and efficiently utilize the available resources to analyze the massive volume of digital evidence. There was an ongoing push to create a standardized system for tracking the evidence and to get the data into a usable format (Relativity) for the review process.

Initially, the FBI’s NY CART Coordinator and a forensic examiner are working to process and transfer data from seized hard drives, phones, and tablets. There are significant delays and misunderstandings regarding the data transfer process, particularly concerning the volume of data (over 1 million documents), the lack of clear identification of devices and their contents, and issues with the data format.  The team needs a reliable system for tracking the transfer of data, including a spreadsheet detailing devices and their associated materials. There are repeated requests for a list of devices and associated data and concerns about the data's usability for taint review.  The team is experiencing challenges with the data's format, specifically issues with file names and the inability to link emails to attachments.  Several individuals express frustration with the process and the need for better communication and organization. The updates highlight difficulties with network issues, staffing levels, and the challenges of handling large volumes of digital evidence.

Virgin Islands.  The FBI contractor is responsible for extracting and preparing the data for review, while the FBI (specifically the NY CART Coordinator) is overseeing the process. Key issues include: *   **Data Volume & Format:** The volume of data (over a million documents) is overwhelming, and the inconsistent formats and lack of clear labeling make review extremely challenging. *   **Identification of Devices:**  A critical need exists for a clear inventory of seized devices and their corresponding data, allowing accurate tracking of what has been processed and what remains. *   **Transfer Issues:**  There are concerns about the transfer process itself, including a delay due to network issues and questions about whether data is being delivered in its entirety or with modifications.  There's confusion about which files have already been provided and what’s newly submitted. *   **Relativity System:** The FBI's reliance on the Relativity e-discovery platform for review is causing difficulties due to Relativity's limitations in handling forensic data. *   **Coordination Challenges:**  Frequent communication and coordination between the involved parties (FBI, contractor, and US Attorney’s office) are essential to address these challenges and maintain progress. The text shows a reactive and somewhat disorganized process, marked by miscommunications and a lack of clear documentation. The overarching goal is to efficiently review the seized data to identify potential evidence and support further legal action.

Thomas Brown of Berkeley Research Group, LLC proposes a computer forensics engagement for approximately 57 devices (hard drives, mobile devices, and portable media). The scope includes data extraction, parsing, Relativity file creation, data analysis, and team briefings. The engagement would be staffed by two junior staff members supervised by a senior staff member (a former FBI computer scientist) and managed by a director. The estimated timeline is 30 days. The budget ranges from $85,000 to $135,000, covering hourly rates for staff and the director, plus fees for blank hard drives, thumb drives, and device image recovery.

A Forensic Accountant (FBI New York Field Office) responded with an attached draft analysis of Maxwell’s credit cards for discussion purposes, subject to change.

A forensic accountant at the FBI New York Field Office prepared an analysis of account numbers related to “Maxwell” within AMEX production. The primary issue revolves around the disorganized and incomplete delivery of data, particularly concerning the massive volume of files (over a million) recovered from multiple devices (computers, hard drives, CDs, etc.) across New York and the US Virgin Islands.  Key points include: *   **Delayed Data Delivery:** Significant delays are experienced in receiving the data, with estimates fluctuating and needing to be pushed back. *   **Data Organization Issues:** The received data is poorly organized, lacking clear identification of devices and contents, making review extremely difficult. There are multiple versions of files. *   **Relativity System Challenges:** The contractor is attempting to utilize Relativity for data review, but the lack of proper organization hinders its effectiveness. The system is unable to easily interpret the data. *   **Request for a Tracking System:**  The team repeatedly requests a standardized spreadsheet or tracking system to manage the data and facilitate the review process. *   **Ongoing Coordination:** The exchanges involve ongoing discussions about timelines, data formats, and the necessary steps to effectively analyze the evidence. Several individuals coordinate to schedule meetings. *   **Technical Difficulties:** Technical issues, such as network problems and the need to rebuild network infrastructure, contribute to the delays. The core problem is the absence of a clear, organized system for tracking the digital evidence, leading to significant delays and challenges in the investigation.

The core issue is a lack of clear organization and tracking of the evidence, leading to repeated delays and confusion. **Key Points:** *   **Data Volume & Complexity:** The investigation involves a massive amount of data across various devices (computers, hard drives, CDs, etc.), making the process incredibly complex. *   **Lack of Tracking:** The primary problem is the absence of a consistent system for identifying and labeling the evidence, making it difficult to determine what’s been reviewed, transferred, and what remains. *   **Processing Issues:** The contractor highlights issues with the data formats received, specifically challenges with Relativity (the e-discovery tool) handling the data and the lack of links between files and devices. *   **Timeline Delays:** Repeated delays are attributed to miscommunication, the need to re-process data, and the sheer volume of evidence. *   **Requests for Clarity:** Throughout the exchanges, the US Attorney's Office and FBI repeatedly request a spreadsheet or other organized listing of the evidence to facilitate the review process. *   **Proposed Solutions:** Various suggestions are made (e.g., creating a spreadsheet, using Bates numbers) to address the tracking problem, but implementation is slow due to the ongoing challenges. Essentially, the document chronicles the frustrating process of trying to manage a large, complex digital evidence case with inadequate organization and communication.

Virgin Islands. Initial communications involve the FBI (specifically, the NY CART Coordinator and Senior Forensic Examiner) working with a contractor to receive data, primarily in the form of hard drives containing digital evidence. Early challenges include data inconsistencies (duplicate files, unclear labeling, and issues with the load file), difficulties in tracking the source of the data (device identification), and problems with the receiving system (Relativity) being unable to properly process and display the files. There are repeated requests for a clear inventory of the seized devices and their contents, a spreadsheet detailing the data transfers, and a coordinated meeting to address these issues. The overall timeline is disrupted due to network maintenance, and concerns arise regarding the lack of organized data to facilitate the forensic review process and eventual production of evidence for legal proceedings.

The core issue revolves around the disorganized and incomplete delivery of data, specifically over a million documents and numerous devices (computers, hard drives, thumb drives, etc.) from Epstein’s residences in New York and the USVI. Key points and concerns raised repeatedly include: *   **Lack of Identification:** There's a critical need for a system to identify and track each device and its corresponding data. The current delivery lacks clear labeling, making review and organization extremely difficult. *   **Duplicate Data:** The team worries about receiving duplicate files and needing to sift through them. *   **Data Formats:** The documents are in varying formats (Mac, Windows, loose media), creating challenges for the review process. Relativity, the e-discovery tool being used, is proving problematic due to its inability to handle the file structure effectively. *   **Timeline Issues:** Multiple delays and shifting estimates are given regarding the completion of the data transfer and analysis, primarily due to network issues and staffing constraints. *   **Coordination Needed:** There's a continuous need for better coordination and clear communication between all parties to ensure the data is processed efficiently and effectively. The exchanges repeatedly request a spreadsheet with detailed information about each device, its contents, and the status of its review.

Virgin Islands. Initially, the FBI (NY CART Coordinator) was sending data in load files, but significant issues arose due to the massive volume of data (over a million documents), difficulties in tracking the origin of files (lack of device identification), and problems with the data format. There were challenges with file naming conventions, data duplication, and the inability of the existing tools (Relativity) to effectively process the data. The U.S. Attorney’s office requested a more organized approach – a spreadsheet detailing each device and its contents – to facilitate the review process. A series of emails between the FBI and the U.S. Attorney’s office outlined the challenges, requests for clarification, and attempts to establish a coordinated workflow, with ongoing discussions about timelines and data transfer methods. The core issue revolved around a lack of clear identification and tracking of the digital evidence, leading to significant delays and difficulties in the review process.

This document details the ongoing efforts to process and analyze digital evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein’s case, primarily from searches conducted in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Initially, the FBI contractor, working under the NY CART Coordinator, was tasked with collecting and preparing the data for review. There were repeated communication challenges regarding the format and organization of the data, with the contractor struggling to reconcile the different data streams and the lack of clear identification of devices and their contents. The volume of data was substantial (over a million documents), creating difficulties in tracking progress and ensuring a cohesive review process. Several attempts were made to establish a clear system for data transfer and identification, including the creation of spreadsheets, but these efforts were hampered by inconsistencies and missing information. There were delays due to network issues and the processing of the data, with the contractor requesting assistance and seeking clarification on timelines and procedures. Ultimately, the need for a coordinated approach and a standardized system for managing the evidence was repeatedly emphasized to ensure efficient and accurate analysis.

An FBI Forensic Accountant at the New York Field Office sent an analysis of Maxwell’s accounts as of 6/30/20 to Ori, requesting updates incorporating information from UBS. This document is an email chain regarding search warrant documents related to Jeffrey Epstein’s case. It includes emails between the USANYs contractor, the FBI, and potentially other individuals. File folders with names like NYC024328, NYC024329, etc., were exchanged, along with a .DS Store file. One email includes contact information for a NYO CART Coordinator and Senior Forensic Examiner.

This document details a series of communications between the FBI’s NY CART Coordinator (Senior Forensic Examiner) and a contractor regarding the digital evidence collected from Seth Rich’s residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands related to Jeffrey Epstein. The primary focus is on the transfer and processing of the data, highlighting significant delays and challenges. Here’s a breakdown of the key content: *   **Initial Data Transfer:** The contractor initially received hard drives containing evidence, with a focus on transferring the data to Relativity for review. *   **Technical Difficulties:** The FBI and contractor encountered numerous technical issues, primarily with the format of the data. The original transfer lacked proper indexing, making it difficult to link emails to attachments and hindering forensic analysis. The data contained a large number of small files, leading to slow transfer times. *   **Requests for Clarification & Organization:** The FBI repeatedly requested a clear inventory of devices and data to facilitate a more organized review process. They specifically needed a spreadsheet detailing devices, transfer status, and file types. *   **Delayed Processing:** The processing of the data was significantly delayed due to network issues, the sheer volume of data, and the challenges of working with different data formats (Mac, Windows, loose media). *   **Ongoing Communication:** Throughout the document, there’s a back-and-forth discussion about timelines, the need for further data transfers, and the challenges of integrating the different data streams. *   **Final Status:** As of the last entry, the process was still ongoing with estimates for completion pushed back due to the complexities involved.

An FBI agent (NYO CART Coordinator, Senior Forensic Examiner) sent an Excel spreadsheet (“EpsteinNYEvidence.xlsx”) to an unknown recipient. The agent is processing a laptop and two desktops, requiring re-processing which may take time and introduce static. They are willing to re-work previously produced materials to separate data, but the impact is uncertain.

This document details the status of evidence items recovered from an investigation, primarily related to Epstein. It lists 77 devices, including laptops, desktops, iPhones, iPads, iMacs, servers, and various storage devices (HDDs, SSDs, SD cards, thumb drives).  Many of these devices were provided by forensic teams (FTK, Blacklight, etc.) and were processed with varying degrees of success. Some devices were already analyzed ("Greykey/Physical analyzer Already provided"), while others required further processing. Several devices were marked as “duplicates” or “non-evidentiary” and were not processed.  Notably, several drives from a UNIFI server and HP Proliant Server required further hardware recovery attempts due to RAID issues. A large number of CDs and SD cards were also included in the evidence.

This document is a discovery disclosure from the U.S. Department of Justice, Southern District of New York, regarding the case of *United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell*. It outlines materials being provided to defense counsel, including: *   **Brady Material Disclosure:** The government is disclosing information under Brady v. Maryland to ensure full disclosure of evidence. While acknowledging this obligation, the government states they are disclosing for “abundance of caution.” *   **Types of Documents:** The disclosure encompasses a vast range of documents, including: bank records (Chase, Capital One, UBS, etc.), travel records (flight manifests, Southwest, United Airlines), phone records (T-Mobile, PayPal), email records (Oath Holdings), financial records (Shoppers Travel, Charles Schwab), and records from various organizations like Microsoft, the New York State Department of State, and professional schools. *   **Requests for Reciprocal Discovery:** The government requests reciprocal discovery, specifically requesting access to the defendant's books, records, and prior statements of witnesses. *   **Sentencing Guidelines:** The government intends to oppose a potential one-point reduction in sentencing based on acceptance of responsibility. *   **Bates and Forensic Start/End Dates:** Specifies Bates and Forensic start and end dates for document retrieval. *   **Control Numbers:** References a series of control numbers (SDNY_GM_00000001 through SDNY_GM_00012841) associated with the disclosed materials.

Dr. Dawn Hughes, a forensic psychologist, provides psychological evaluations for legal purposes, working with law firms as clients. Evaluations involve interviews, testing, document review, and report preparation.  Confidentiality is maintained, with information shared with the litigant's attorney. Fees are $500 per hour, with specific billing rates for court testimony and disbursements. A $7000 retainer is required, with $3500 non-refundable, and the final cost depends on the scope of the evaluation. All agreements must be in writing and signed by Dr. Hughes and an authorized representative of the law firm.

On October 13, 2020, a NY FBI CART Coordinator is coordinating with a POC regarding devices and media related to Jeffrey Epstein’s case, obtained through a CAIR system.  The Coordinator has provided access to machines and exports to the SDNY office.  Another individual, Stephen, is the POC for that week. The FBI is requesting updates and ensuring no delays occur due to attention from the Executive Management (EM).

On November 4, 2020, Neil (liIIM) responded to Dawn Hughes regarding an offer to provide expert testimony as a clinical and forensic psychologist in the trial of *United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell*. The trial was scheduled for July 12, 2021, in the Southern District of New York. An individual (NY CART Coordinator, Senior Forensic Examiner) is conducting redaction analysis on EFTA00025276.pdf, specifically focusing on 41 Mac computers. They have successfully exported data from 5 machines, with 8 remaining. The individual anticipates completing the remaining exports with 2 machines tomorrow.

Dr. Rocchio is a forensic and clinical psychologist with 20+ years of experience specializing in trauma-related cases, including child sexual abuse, intimate partner violence, and related litigation. Her expertise includes evaluating victims of abuse, providing legal consultation, and offering expert testimony in both civil and criminal matters. She has experience with various types of abuse, including grooming, delayed reporting, trauma bonding, and complex trauma. She has worked with both male and female victims, and has experience with perpetrators including fathers and mothers. She has testified in Massachusetts criminal trials and has been deposed. She collaborates with US Attorneys and assists in civil litigation involving victims of abuse.

This document is a series of FBI communications (dated February 2, 2021 – February 24, 2021) regarding an interview with a victim of Jeffrey Epstein. The communications involve coordinating logistics (time, location) for the interview, primarily between Special Agents at the FBI New York Field Office and an unidentified individual ("She"). There’s discussion about scheduling the interview, a trauma-focused therapist referral, and potential locations for the interview. Several pieces of information have been redacted.

FBI agents are coordinating a meeting with a victim of Jeffrey Epstein. Initial communication involved scheduling an interview for February 23, 2021, with the individual, who had previously provided information to the FBI. One agent is assisting with forensic interviews and suggesting contact with another agent in the New York Field Office. There is discussion about the victim’s need for a trauma-focused therapist and seeking recommendations for nearby office locations.

Dr. Rocchio has over 25 years of experience working with survivors of sexual trauma, beginning with her post-doctoral work at Yale and continuing in private practice since 1998. Her client population has historically been primarily women with suicidal tendencies and experiences of trauma, with a significant portion (currently around 50%) having experienced childhood sexual abuse. She has conducted assessments for courts involving juveniles with mental health difficulties and significant trauma exposure. Dr. Rocchio is the president-elect of the APA trauma committee and a fellow of the organization. She has received specialized training in violence against women, trauma treatment, and forensic assessment of trauma in both civil and criminal settings, treating at least 20 clients annually.

On March 8, 2021, Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, r.0, represented by Laura A. Menninger, formally requested the opportunity to view physical evidence, “Highly Confidential” materials, and physical scenes related to the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). They proposed a review period of March 17-18, 2021, anticipating multiple eight-hour sessions with Ms. Maxwell’s presence. The firm requested a log of seized evidence and proposed scheduling scene visits within the next month, subject to travel arrangements.

This document concerns the discovery process in the US v. Maxwell case, specifically regarding the review of highly confidential evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein’s activities. The US Attorney’s office, represented by an Assistant US Attorney, is facilitating the review of electronic images and physical evidence held by the FBI. Key points include: *   **Types of Evidence:** The FBI possesses three categories of electronic images related to nude/partially nude images: approximately 2,100 electronic images and videos from Epstein’s devices, 3,400 discs from his residences, and 7 hard copy images from the FBI Florida office. *   **Review Access:** The defense team (represented by Laura Menninger of Haddon, Morgan & Foreman) will have access to the electronic files, with Cellebrite software provided for viewing Apple devices. The physical evidence will be reviewed at the FBI’s Bronx warehouse under specific conditions. *   **Logistics:** The warehouse review requires two weeks' notice and is open during business hours. The FBI will provide one laptop for image review and can transport items to 500 Pearl Street. *   **Restrictions:** Duplicates of the obscene electronic images are prohibited, and there are limitations on the number of laptops available.  Electronic media (VHS, cassettes, CDs) are not playable at the warehouse. *   **Timeline & Communication:** The Attorney and defense team are coordinating scheduling for the review, with the FBI anticipating a three-week timeframe for reviewing all electronic media at their Manhattan office.  The defense team is requesting information about the timeline for reviewing the evidence and the availability of an index of physical evidence.

Maxwell case, involving highly confidential materials. The review will primarily occur at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse in New York, with some evidence to be viewed at the FBI’s Bronx warehouse. Initially, the FBI intends to make evidence available for review beginning April 13th, daily, until the review is complete. The defense team will be accompanied by an Assistant US Attorney and an FBI agent. Key points include: *   **Initial Scheduling:** The defense team and the government have agreed to a meeting at 11:00 AM on April 12th at the Bronx warehouse to photograph excluded items. *   **Physical Evidence Location:** The vast majority of physical evidence will be transported to 500 Pearl Street for review. *   **Highly Confidential Items:**  The FBI will provide the defense team with laptops to review 2,100 electronic images and 7 hard-copy images classified as “highly confidential”. The defense team requested clarification about the handling of these materials. *   **Logistical Arrangements:** The FBI will ensure a secure environment and separate review space for the defense team. *   **Ongoing Questions and Clarifications:** The defense team raised several questions regarding the process, including the availability of equipment, the handling of non-testifying witness statements, and access to a full inventory of physical evidence.

This document details the opinions and conclusions of Dr. Lisa Rocchio, a forensic and clinical psychologist with 30+ years of experience in psychology, trauma, and interpersonal violence. Her expertise stems from assessing survivors of childhood sexual abuse and working in the forensic arena. Key points include: *   **Established Knowledge Base:** Dr. Rocchio relies on decades of research and clinical experience across various fields, including forensic psychology, trauma psychology, and clinical assessment. *   **Grooming Process:** She describes the "grooming" process – where perpetrators establish trust and rapport with victims through manipulation, gradually normalizing inappropriate behavior and creating dependency. This often involves building relationships with family members, offering gifts, and initiating conversations about sexual activity. *   **Variability of Abuse:** She acknowledges that abuse varies significantly based on individual and situational factors, sometimes occurring as a crime of opportunity, and sometimes escalating over time. *   **Delayed Disclosure:**  The document highlights the common phenomenon of delayed disclosure of abuse, attributing it to factors like shame, fear of consequences, and the victim's desire to maintain a relationship with the perpetrator. *   **Memory & Trauma:** It explains how traumatic memories are reconstructed, often with limited detail, influenced by the salience of events and the individual's coping mechanisms. *   **Myth Busting:** It addresses common myths about sexual assault, such as the belief that it always occurs through violent attacks by strangers. *   **Multiple Perpetrators:** The document discusses how multiple individuals can contribute to grooming and abuse, sometimes facilitating the process through their presence or actions. *   **Contextual Factors:**  The document emphasizes the importance of understanding the relationships between victims and perpetrators, including the potential for multiple perpetrators and the impact of societal factors. Essentially, Dr. Rocchio presents a comprehensive overview of the psychological complexities surrounding child sexual abuse, emphasizing the intricate dynamics of trust, manipulation, and the lasting impact on victims.

The United States Attorney’s Office, via the Southern District of New York, is responding to a request from defense counsel to review sixteen DVD-R discs held by the FBI. These discs, labeled with Palm Beach County Sheriffs Office case information, are identified as a forensic image of a computer (the “Epstein Computer”) seized from Jeffrey Epstein’s residence in 2005. The FBI was unable to access the files on the discs due to their inoperability. The Government now asserts it lacks a lawful basis to review the image, citing the absence of a warrant authorizing content review and the passage of time since the computer’s seizure. Furthermore, the estate of Epstein has refused to waive attorney-client privileges, preventing a privilege review before any potential examination of the discs. Consequently, the Government states the discs are not discoverable.

Dr. Rocchio’s expertise stems from a career-long focus on traumatic stress, clinical and forensic psychology, and the treatment of trauma survivors. Her testimony is based on her education, training, research, and experience, particularly regarding childhood sexual abuse. Key points include: *   The complexities of trauma, including “complex trauma” resulting from repeated or prolonged abuse, significantly impacting psychological development and leading to conditions like PTSD. *   Victims often exhibit strategic behaviors to obscure abuse and build trust, hindering awareness and disclosure. *   Memory of abuse is influenced by various factors and is not always a complete or accurate representation. *   Sexual abuse frequently involves manipulation and coercion within established relationships, not necessarily forcible rape. *   Dr. Rocchio’s work includes forensic evaluations, training, and committee involvement within the APA.

The document is a notice from the U.S. Department of Justice to legal counsel regarding the upcoming trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, case number 20 Cr. 330 (MN). The Government intends to call a clinical expert witness, M., to testify about the patterns of manipulation and grooming that frequently occur in sexual abuse cases involving minors, and how these factors impact victim awareness and disclosure. The Government is also requesting reciprocal discovery regarding any expert witnesses the defense intends to use, along with a request for inspection of the defendant's documents and prior statements of witnesses.

Ghislaine Maxwell*, is providing notice of Computer Forensic Examiner Stephen’s anticipated testimony. The U.S. Department of Justice, specifically the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, is communicating with defense counsel regarding the upcoming trial in *United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330). The government intends to use testimony from a Computer Forensic Examiner from the FBI’s CART team. This Examiner will detail device extractions, user information, and documents obtained through court-authorized searches. On October 7, 2021, a forensic accountant with the FBI New York Field Office sent account opening, signature, and KYC documents related to two accounts associated with Ghislaine Maxwell to another recipient. The documents, including a June 2007 statement, were uploaded to the DOJ USA File Exchange site. On October 7, 2021, a forensic accountant with the FBI New York Field Office sent documents related to Epstein accounts to FBI agents in New York. The documents included account statements, removal memos requesting the removal of Ghislaine Maxwell from various accounts (Hyperion Air, Jeffery Epstein, NES LLC), and access instructions to a DOJ USA File Exchange folder.  A follow-up email on October 6, 2021, requested account statements for a few months after the documents were executed.  EFTA00021665 was the file identifier.

Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). It’s submitted pursuant to Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16(b)(1)(C). *   **Expert Witnesses:** The defense intends to use the following expert witnesses: *   **Dr. Elizabeth Loftus:** A psychologist specializing in memory, intended to testify about the science of memory, false memories, and the influence of suggestion. *   **Dr. Park Dietz:** A psychiatrist specializing in forensic psychiatry, intended to testify about grooming behavior, mental health issues, and the potential for biased judgments. *   **Dr. Ryan Hall:** A forensic chemist and document dating specialist, intended to analyze documents and assess their authenticity. *   **Jennifer Naso:** A forensic document examiner, intended to examine and determine the authorship and authentication of documents. *   **Mr. John Lopez:** A former IRS-CI Special Agent, intended to testify about financial records. *   **Key Arguments Regarding “Grooming”:** The defense anticipates challenging the prosecution’s use of the term "grooming," arguing that it carries an unwarranted implication of intent and can lead to misleading judgments, specifically regarding hindsight bias and the potential for individuals with mental health conditions to be wrongly accused. *   **Other Arguments:** The defense intends to highlight potential pathways to false sexual assault allegations, including factors like memory distortions, psychological vulnerabilities (e.g., personality disorders), and the influence of external information (media coverage). *   **Reservations:** The defense reserves the right to supplement its disclosures and call additional experts as needed throughout the trial.

This document presents the professional profile of Lisa M. Rocchio, Ph.D., a clinical psychologist specializing in trauma, forensic psychology, and dissociative disorders. Here’s a breakdown of the key information: *   **Education:** She holds a Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from the University of Rhode Island, preceded by Master’s and Bachelor’s degrees. *   **Licensure:** She is a licensed psychologist in Massachusetts, New York, and Rhode Island, holding multiple licenses. *   **Clinical Experience:** Rocchio has extensive clinical experience, including directing an independent group practice, working in hospital settings (Butler Hospital, Brown University), and conducting evaluations and assessments for a wide range of cases, including forensic assessments, eating disorders, and trauma-related issues. *   **Training and Specialized Skills:** She has extensive training in areas like EMDR, DBT, and forensic psychology, and has pursued various continuing education certifications. *   **Research and Publications:** Rocchio has engaged in research, contributing to publications and presenting at conferences. *   **Professional Activities & Advocacy:** She is an active member of several professional organizations (APA, AWP, ISSTD, etc.), participating in committees, advocating for mental health issues, and holding leadership positions within these organizations. She has also been involved in local Rhode Island community governance.

The organization is a certified Rape Crisis Center and provides crisis response, advocacy, therapy, and community awareness programs. **Key Features:** *   **Mission:** To provide compassion and respect to crime victims regardless of race, sex, or other demographic factors. *   **Services Offered:** Individual therapy, support groups, forensic exams (through the Butterfly House), criminal justice advocacy, victim compensation assistance, and 24/7 crisis support. *   **Start by Believing Campaign:** A public awareness initiative focused on changing responses to sexual violence. *   **Multiple Locations:** Services are offered from several locations within Palm Beach County. *   **Funding:** The organization is funded through the Palm Beach County Board of County Commissioners, grants from the Office of the Attorney General, and the Florida Council Against Sexual Violence. *   **Florida Statute 960 Rights:** Victims have specific rights outlined in Florida Statute 960, including information, participation in proceedings, and prompt case resolution. *   **Resources:** The document provides contact information for Palm Beach County Victim Services, the Florida Council Against Sexual Violence, and other relevant organizations. *   **Types of Crime Coverage:** Support is available for victims of sexual assault, domestic violence, homicide, and other violent crimes. The document includes detailed information on how to access services, including specific contact numbers and addresses for various locations within Palm Beach County.  It also outlines eligibility requirements for victim compensation and provides information on forensic exam procedures and victim rights.

Preston M. Faro, a forensic accountant and private investigator, was hired by Cohen & Gresser LLP to review a Financial Condition Report prepared by Macalvins Accountants for Ghislaine Maxwell’s finances from 2015-2020.  His background includes over 40 years of experience in financial fraud investigations, including prior work as an IRS Special Agent and involvement in the World Trade Center Integrity Compliance Program.  During the review, he examined the Financial Condition Report, Independent Accountants’ Commentary, and supporting Excel schedules, accessing underlying documents and questioning Macalvins accountants. He concluded that the report accurately summarized Ms. Maxwell’s assets.

Rocchio, Ph.D., is a licensed clinical psychologist with extensive experience in forensic psychology, trauma treatment, and private practice.** **Education & Credentials:** She holds a Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from the University of Rhode Island and has licenses in Massachusetts, New York, and Rhode Island. **Clinical Experience:** She’s been involved in a diverse range of clinical roles including: *   Clinical Director and Owner of Inter-Disciplinary Independent Group Practice since 1998. *   Post-doctoral fellow at Butler Hospital (Women’s Day Hospital Program) and Yale University School of Medicine. *   Clinical Externships at various university counseling centers and Brown University. **Specialized Training & Expertise:** Rocchio has completed numerous specialized training programs in areas like: *   Forensic Psychology (AAFP), including evaluations of feigned psychopathology and stalking assessments. *   Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDRIA). *   Dialectical Behavior Therapy (Behavioral Technology Transfer Group). *   Trauma Psychology (ISSTD). **Research & Publications:** She has been involved in research related to eating disorders, psychological injury, and complex trauma. She has authored or co-authored several publications in the field. **Professional Activities & Advocacy:** Rocchio is an active member of several professional organizations including the APA, AWP, and ISSTD, and has participated in legislative advocacy concerning mental health parity and healthcare reform.  She has also served on various committees within these organizations and on the boards of local schools (Moses Brown School).
